q:
What will be the output for this Ruby on Rails code?

Code

#!/usr/bin/ruby
class Example
VARx = 100
VARy = 200
def show
puts "Value of the first constant is #{VARx}"
puts "Value of the second constant is #{VARy}"
end
end

# Create Objects
object=Example.new()
object.show

Output:

  1.  Value of the first constant is 100
 Value of the second constant is 200
  2.  Value of the first constant is 200
 Value of the second constant is 100
  3.  Value of the first constant is #{VARx}
 Value of the second constant is #{VARy}
  4. Compilation Error

q:
What is the ouput of the following Ruby code?

Code:

class Mobile
  @name
  @model
  @cost 
  def initialize(name,model,cost)
    @name = name
    @model = model
    @cost = cost
  end
  def setName(name)
    @name = name
  end 
  def getName()
    puts "#{@name}"
  end
end
mobile = mobile.new("Apple",2022,10000000)
mobile.setname("Samsung")
mobile.getname()

Code:

a=1
b=2
while (a <5 || b<5)&&true

  2. 1
625
  3. 1
2

counter = 2
while counter < 100

  counter=counter+1

256

676

Alice is working on Sessions and Cookies from Ruby on Rails. She wants to use a cookie to store a unique ID that looks up for each session data on the server like a database table. Now, if she is required to implement various storage mechanisms to perform this request, then which of the following statements about these storage mechanisms are correct:

Statements

  1. If she implements the storage mechanism ActionDispatch::Session::CookieStore, it can store everything on the client. This is the default and recommended session store that stores all session data in the cookie itself.
  2. If she implements the storage mechanism ActionDispatch::Session::CacheStore, it can store the data in the Rails cache.
  3. If she implements the storage mechanism ActionDispatch::Session::RecordStore, it can store the data in the database using Active Record.
  4. If she implements the storage mechanism ActionDispatch::Session::MemCacheStore, it can store the data in a Memcached cluster.

Code:

def sample
    @post = Post.new(params[:post])
    respond_to do |format|
    Post.html
    Post.json  { render :json => @posts }
    format.html { redirect_to @post, notice: 'Post is updated.' }
    format.json { render json:@post, status: :create, location: @post }
    end
end

What is the output of the following Ruby code?

Code:

class Company
    attr_accessor:color,:name   
end
class HackerEarth < Company
    def initialize(name,color)
        @name = name
        @color = color
    end
    def speak
        return "Great...!!!"
    end
end
hackerearth = hackerearth.new("HE",'Blue')
puts hackerearth.inspect
puts hackerearth.speak

Options:

  1. #<HackerEarth:0x262fa88 @name="HE" , @color="Blue">
Great...!!!
  2. HE
Blue
Great...!!!
